newsitem.title: NIGERIA: Nigeria sets up tribunal to try erring contractors.
newsitem.headline: Nigeria sets up tribunal to try erring contractors.

text.p: Nigeria's military government has set up a tribunal to try contractors who failed to carry out work they were paid millions of dollars for.

Finance minister Anthony Ani said on Monday at a briefing on the 1997 budget that the Failed Parastatals Contract Tribunal would investigate 18 projects on which about $836 million was spent but which were not implemented.
He said that last year, officials from the Federal Finance Ministry toured 30 Nigerian states to evaluate 145 projects financed with loans amounting to over $13 billion.
The team discovered 18 projects which were not carried out and termed them as "failed", Ani said, adding: "The proceeds were drawn and the contracts were purported to have been executed."
All those involved in the 18 "failed" projects would be brought before the tribunal and punished if found guilty. Government would extradite anyone involved who had fled abroad, he said.
In 1995, Nigeria set up the failed banks tribunal to try all those believed to have made off with sums of money and contributed to the problems that hit the banking sector.
Many businessmen and former bank executives have either been jailed or are in detention awaiting trial by the tribunal.
